author: Special Correspondent
text:
While terming the Union Budget as pro-farmer, Tirunelveli District Small and Tiny Industries Association (NELSTIA) secretary Sanjay Gunasingh opined that more incentives and allocation could have been made to invigorate the industrial sector also.

Airing his views on the Union budget 2016 – 2017, Mr. Sanjay said the Finance Minister’s plan to double the farmers’ income by 2020 by ensuring adequate financial allocation and providing the right market to sell their produce was a welcome move. Being the country’s largest sector providing employment to millions of workers, the move should improve farmers’ living standards.

He said the proposal to establish 5,700 special institutions across the country for imparting special multi skills to youths would enable them to acquire employable qualities and skills. At the same time, he cautioned that the proposed schools should not be established in the Industrial Training Institute format.

The proposal to incorporate better facilities in 160 airports across India and Rs.2.18 lakh crore in the rail and road development sectors would infuse the much-needed vigour in the tourism and industrial sectors.

The reduction in corporate tax from existing 33 per cent to 24.80 per cent enthused entrepreneurs.

He welcomed the proposal of deferring the customs and excise duty declaration for exporters and importers with clean track record would provide some relief to them while encouraging others to maintain good track record.

“At the same time, we expected more incentives that can boost productivity in the small and tiny industries sector as it is also providing employment to several millions of skilled and unskilled labourers,” Mr. Sanjay said.
title: Pro-farmer budget: NELSTIA
